awd_titl_txt: NRI: INT: COLLAB: Distributed co-Robots for Strawberry Harvesting
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently, strawberry production in the United States is decreasing due to labor shortages and the ever-increasing cost of labor, particularly for harvesting. A high cost of production could put strawberry-growers in the U.S. at a disadvantage in comparison to countries whose cost of labor is much less. In order to make strawberry production in the U.S. competitive with the rest of the world, production costs need to be reduced. This project aims to investigate developing a small, rugged, and cost-effective co-robot system that can be used by growers, which will ultimately lower the harvesting costs and increase profitability of strawberry production. Additionally, the research results can benefit other high value specialty crops, such as tomatoes and blueberries, as they are facing similar labor shortage issues. This multi-disciplinary research will enrich course curricula which benefits a large number of students at three participating universities, and will provide research and development experiences to students of underrepresented and minority backgrounds. The outreach component of the project will educate K-12 students and the general public about robotics in agriculture via conferences, workshops, field days, and other learning engagement activities. Additionally, a graphic user interface will be developed, which is adaptable as an assistive device to benefit users with disabilities. 

The project includes three primary research thrusts. The first thrust will investigate a decentralized, scalable row allocation algorithm for robots to achieve a consensus about which rows to harvest, in order to achieve an overall minimum time in harvesting. The algorithm is expected to be scalable, efficient, fast, non-conflicting, and simple. The second thrust will develop an integrated multi-exposure fusion, curvature analysis and hierarchical image processing algorithm. Supported by the end-to-end deep learning technique, the algorithm will detect strawberries, stems, and vines in field environments with a high accuracy. The third research thrust involves a study of a parallel delta robot-arm based manipulation system for picking and transporting harvested fruits. The associated amount of movements will be minimized. These three thrusts will be complemented by many other engineering tasks and a detailed cost analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Background:

The need for sustainable and efficient agricultural practices has led to a global shift towards robotic technologies in farming, addressing labor shortages and minimizing crop inputs. Robotic solutions are particularly crucial for labor-intensive tasks such as fruit harvesting, and weeding because of decreasing availability and increasing cost of farm labor. To address this challenge in strawberry farming, this project focused on developing deep learning models for precise strawberry detection, and pickability determination as well as developing innovative approaches for handling occlusion during fruit picking. Major project outcomes are discussed below.

Intellectual Merits:

Real-time Strawberry Detection with YOLOv5s-Straw: An improved YOLOv5s-based detection model was developed to accurately detect strawberries in open-field environments, overcoming issues like false detection and poor localization. The model achieved a high mean average precision (mAP) of 80.3%, outperforming other competitive models. YOLOv5s-Straw was particularly effective in identifying strawberries at various maturity stages (mature, nearly mature, immature) and demonstrated higher process speed compared to other commonly used deep learning models, making it well-suited for real-time strawberry harvesting systems.

Two-step Model for Pickability Classification: A two-step deep learning model was designed for strawberry detection and for determining the pickability of mature strawberries. The first stage used an enhanced YOLOv8s model for accurate strawberry detection, while the second stage applied YOLOv5s-cls to classify strawberries as pickable or unpickable. The combined two-step model achieved high accuracy in both detection and classification, with an mAP of 83.2%, and demonstrated strong performance in field tests, improving the overall effectiveness of the robotic harvesting system.

Occlusion Handling with a Robotic Strawberry Harvester: To address the challenge of occlusion in strawberry canopies, a robotic harvester (Figure 1) was developed featuring a vision-based occlusion detection system and an innovative fan-equipped end-effector to disperse leaves blocking fruits. The robot's picking efficiency improved by 15.8% when using the fan system, achieving a picking rate of 73.9% compared to 58.1% without it.

Broader Impacts:

The advancements made in the vision system and occlusion handling mechanisms showed the promise for a more precise and robust robotic harvesting system, thus increasing the viability of the system. When commercially adopted by farmers, the technology is expected to minimize the dependence on farm labor and reduce the cost in producing strawberries, thus ensuring sustainable production of higher-quality produce. The technology developed could also be used in various other tasks in fruit crops such as crop yield estimation, and pest control broadening its impact beyond strawberry harvesting. Wider adoption of these technologies will increase access to nutritious food to the general public at affordable costs.

Beyond agriculture, the project’s innovations have applicability in fields such as autonomous vehicles, industrial automation, transportation, construction, surveillance, and human-robot collaboration. For example, the deep learning models and adaptive manipulation systems developed for strawberry harvesting contribute to advancements in object recognition, classification, and handling of soft obstacles that could be adapted to industries such as autonomous vehicles, and construction.

The project also supported the establishment of state-of-the-art infrastructure for evaluating robotic systems in field conditions. This infrastructure included RGB-D cameras and materials to build a sensing platform, as well as laboratory setups to integrate and calibrate vision systems and robotic components. Additionally, the project contributed to the development of innovative robotic mechanisms, such as a robotic arm with a novel end-effector and a vision-guided system. These resources provide a robust experimental framework for future research initiatives at Washington State University and will help continue innovation in agricultural robotics nationwide and for training the next generation of the workforce. 

Within this project, one PhD student (Dr. Zixuan He) was trained, who recently graduated and is joining Aarhus University in Denmark as a post-doctoral researcher. Dr. He published his work in reputed journals and presented in various conferences nationally and internationally. His novel contribution was recognized with prestigious awards including the 2024 Giuseppe Pellizzi Prize (Club of Bologna, Italy), and 2023 Most Outstanding Student by the International Society of Precision Agriculture.  PI Karkee also used the findings of this project in his class on Machine Vision Systems, thus helping more than 20 graduate students in learning the challenges in farming and advancing robotic solutions to address those challenges. In addition, three undergraduate interns were trained on robotic technologies and their impact on agriculture.

The project outputs and outcomes were disseminated to various stakeholders through technology demonstrations and presentations. Some examples include “The 2024 WSU Technology Open House (Figure 2) ”, “The 2024 Asia Leadership Conference, South Korea”, and “The 2023 Senate Commerce Committee Forum on Future of AI, Seattle”. Through these activities, a direct contact of >500 was made with stakeholder groups including farmers, technology companies, policymakers, government agencies, students (including K-12), scientists, and engineers from around the world thus contributing to a broader understanding of the benefit of robotic technologies in farming, to to stakeholder education, and technology transfer.


Last Modified: 12/16/2024
Modified by: Manoj Karkee

Images (1 of )
  • A prototype robotic strawberry harvester including a machine vision system, manipulator, end-effector, and a ground platform.
    Zixuan He
    Copyrighted
    Manoj Karkee
    Fig. 1
  • Stakeholders including farmers, technology developers, researchers, policy makers and government agency leaders attending the 2024 Technology Open House at WSU Center for Precision and Automated Agricultural Systems
    Manoj Karkee
